solution.text:
In the reaction above, we know that:
\(\Delta U_ {mole} = - _{j}_\frac{kJ}{mol}\)
Also note that \(25 C = 298 K\)

We know that \(\Delta H = \Delta U + n_gRT \)
\(\Delta n_g = \sum\) (Moles of Gaseous Reactant) - \(\sum\) (Moles of Gaseous Product)
\(\implies \Delta n_g = 1-2 = -1\)

Thus, Enthalpy Change per mole \((\Delta H_ {mole})\) for the reaction = \(\Delta U_ {mole} - 1 * 0.0083 * 298\) = \(- _{{j + (0.0083*298)}}_\;\frac{kJ}{mol}\)

content.text:
The following reaction is conducted in a calorimeter at a pressure of 1 atm and a temperature of 25 C.

\(C(s) + 2H_2(g) \rightarrow CH_4(g)\)

During the reaction, the \(\Delta U_ {mole}\) was found to be \(-_{j}_ \frac {kJ}{mol}\). What is the enthalpy change per mole for the above reaction at 25 C and 1 atmosphere?
